answers.answer: Hi,I understand your concern regarding the diagnosis and the symptoms present. Hashimoto's thyroiditis, a condition caused by inflammation of the thyroid gland  is an autoimmune disease. The body inappropriately attacks the thyroid gland  like a  foreign tissue and the underlying cause of the autoimmune process remains unknown. It tends to occur in families and can be associated with other autoimmune conditions such as type 1 diabetes or celiac disease. If the prescription medications are not helping, it is best that you inform your attending physician about this for proper management. You may benefit from a referral to a specialist. Identifying and avoiding the triggers of your migraine may also help. Take care and do keep us posted.

question: I have been diagnosed with Hemiplegic Migraines that began September 2012.  I have a daily headache with intermittent symptoms of right face drooping, difficulty speaking, numbness and pin and needles on right side.  I also of periodic episodes of increased symptoms, nausea, unable to move, bottom jaw chatters and right arm trembles.  I take Gabepentin and Verapamil for prevention, but still have all these symptoms daily.  I also have Hashimoto's Thyroiditis and have been wondering if this is really an autoimmune problem and would like to find a doctor who can help me.
title: Hemiplegic Migraine
